rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Le cadre et le milieu dans les romans d’Edouard Estaunié.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of French Language and Literature
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "Etre un exécutant d'une absolue probité, ne rien livrer qui ne soit l'expression totale et personnelle de ce qu'on a senti, perçu ou pensé, voilàla première règle que vous tous, si je ne me trompe, souhaitez voir aujourd'hui mettre en lumière..."(...) Tels sont les mots d'Estaunie lui-même,comme il s'adressait à ses confrères à un banquet donné en son honneur au moment de sa réception à l'Académie. En regardant la vie d'Estaunie onpense immédiatement que peu d'hommes de lettres ont eu comme lui, une vie qui leur ait donné une telle occasion d'observer le monde, et de leconnaître. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French Literature.
Estaunié, Édouard, 1862-1942 -- Criticism and interpretation.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some observations on the animal ecology of Molson’s Creek.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It has been shown that very little work has been done on the ecology of streams. In Canada practically nothing has been done except in the interestof the fisheries. The value and place of such fresh water studies in our present civilization should be appreciated more than they have.The investigation of Molson's Creek is strictly that of synecology, that is, the stream as a whole. The present work merely records environmentalconditions and illustrates the fundamental principles underlying the balance of nature in most stream habitats. The author intends to enlarge thepresent work later when additional observations will justify the establishment of natural laws and a more detailed study of habitats. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Animal ecology.
Zoology.
Freshwater ecology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L’étude du paysan dans l’oeuvre de René Bazin.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of French Language and Literature
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Le sujet du paysan ou de la vie pastorale et champêtre a été traité dans beaucoup de pays et sous presque toutes les formes selon la mode littérairede l'epoque. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: French Literature.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Capital accumulation in Canada since Confederation.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The selection of the subject of capital accumulation was motivated by the desire to fix our attention upon one particular phenomenon the understanding of which would be of the greatest assistance towards the understaad1ag of the complex of economic forces. With such a purpose in view, this phenomenon obviously had to be analysed in terms of a theory capable of explaining the workings of the economic system as a whole. (...)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics.
Capital.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The vapour density of sulphur dioxide at 0.00C.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]The manner in which the density of a gas depends on its pressure and temperature has been studied ever since chemistry became an exact science.[...] With a view to the low pressures at which the density measurements, given later in this thesis, were made, only those methods employed atcorresponding pressures, and yielding results of fairly high precision, will be given. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The direction of coiling in the chromonemata of Trillium erectum l.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The present investigation was undertaken in an effort to determine whether some consistent explanation could be found to account for the direction ofcoiling of the chromonamata in the chromosomes of the first meiotic division of Trillium erectum L., or if not, to establish the haphazardnature of the coiling mechanism. The meiotic divisions of this plant have been reported on in detail by Huskins and Smith (...) who also madepreliminary observations on the direction of coiling. These observations have been extended and further data have been obtainedfrom plants in which pairing has been prevented by the application of abnormally high temperatures during meiosis. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Trillium erectum.
Genetics.
Plant chromosomes.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Study of Water Balance in the "Alarm Reaction."
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The effect of the "Alarm Reaction" upon the excretion of the intravenously injeQted 0.85;6 sodium chloride solution has been studied in the rat.The "Alarming" stimuli used have been surgical trauma and intraperitoneal histamine injections.The results of Selye have been confirmed in that there has been a marked tendency to develop oedema under the conditions of alarm."The degree of water retention is less ·prolonged in the case of single injections of histamine than in the case of surgical operations, butparallels the severity of the damage.No clear effect of cortin in affecting the rate of excretion of water and salt has been demonstrated in the intact "alarmed" animal.In the adrenalectomized animal cortin does not affect the rate of water excretion in the 'non-alarmed' animal.Cortin markedly increases the rate of excretion of injected water and salt in adrenelectomized "alarmed" animals.After pretreatment with histamine the effect of this substance in producing water retention in adrenalectomized animals is much lessened.Theories of the mechanism of action of the "Alarm Reaction" in producing water end ·salt retention and Cortin in, discharging it are discussed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The stark effect for argon and for krypton.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In a field of 100 Kv./cm. Stark effects have been observed for eighty-six normal levels in argon, and for seventy-five in krypton.Thirty-four electric combination 1ines have been found in argon and forty-eight in krypton. Typical sections of the energy leve1 diagrams for Ne, A,Kr, and Xe are drawn to represent the normal levels and their Stark effects. The diagrams serve as a basis for the qualitative explanation of themain features observed.Since 1nbercombinations between terms of high and low limit respectively are much weaker in neon than in argon; it is found that in the former gasthe Stark effects for the two sets of terms are much more nearly independent.The reversal of the direction of displacement of several terms in argon and krypton with increasing field is discussed.The number of Stark terms deduced from observations in the fie1d is never greater than the number of m values a11owed by the j vaLue of the term.Several lines in the arc spectra of argon and krypton are identified by their Stark effects.No Stark effects have been observed for the spark lines which appear on the plates.Certain corrections to the earlier work by Hyde are suggested.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Design and Fabrication of a 3-wavelength Optical Demultiplexer in Glass
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In this work, the design, simulation and optimization of a Mach-Zehnder 3-wavelength optical demultiplexer (MZ-3WDM) have been performed using a combination of the effective index method (EIM) and the 20 finite difference vectorial beam propagation method (FD-VBPM). Furthermore, the theoretical design and performance predictions of the demultiplexer are verified experimentally through device fabrication and measurements. […]

Dans ce travail, la conception, la simulation et l'optimisation d'un démultiplexeur optique de 3-longueurs d'onde de Mach-Zehnder (MZ-3WDM) ont été exécutées en utilisant une combinaison de la méthode pertinente d'incrément (EIM) et de la méthode vectoriel de propagation de faisceau de la 2D différence finie (FD-VBPM). En outre, la conception et les prévisions théoriques d'exécution du démultiplexeur sont vérifiées expérimentalement par la fabrication et les mesures de dispositif. […]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Optical Demultiplexer

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some fission products of furans and lignin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The discovery of Furoic acid as a pyrolysis product of Mucic acid by Scheele 1) in 1780, opened up a ·complex and extremely interesting field or chemistry. In spite of the early discovery of furans, knowledge of this particular branch of organic chemistry is still very limited. Most attempts at determination of structure by substitution and addition reactions have failed, since furan and substituted furans are highly sensitive to the action of mineral acids. In most cases,these bring about the formation of tars, resins and heavy olls of such complex structures that it has been impossible as yet, to determine their nature. The sensitivity of the furan Qampounds depends upon the nature of substituent groups, and as. one consequence, considerable work has been carried out on the more stable furoic acid.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fission products

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Microfloral and soil treatment studies relative to the control of common scab of potato due to actinomyces scabies.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of these studies 1s two-fold; first, to determine by cultural and soil tests whether or not the occurrence of scab 1s affected byantagonism between Actinomyces spp., causing scab, and other soil micro-organisms; second, to determine the effectiveness of applying chemicals tothe soil as a control measure for scab and the relationship, if any, between the activity of the chemicals as measured by scab control and theoxidation-reduction potentials of the soils used. The dual nature of the studies to follow necessitates dividing this thesis into two parts.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plant Pathology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The geology of a section of Mount Royal near the new building of the University of Montréal.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]In as much as the purpose of this thesis is a description of an area on the mountain, it seems unprofitable to devote much space to a consideration of the relatively scientifically sterile problem of nomenclature. Rock descriptions are, therefore, generallized and a minimum of emphasis is placed on the names. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on the problem of improving the vitamin A value of winter produced milk. : Part I. A comparison of the composition of pasture herbage and green cut cereals ; Part II. The carotene and vitamin A content of milk produced during the winter.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]In order to have carotene present in the winter ration of dairy cows, it is necessary to cure the green herbage in such a way that the carotene will be preserved and not destroyed during the curing process. Sun curing results in a loss of carotene. The carotene present in the cured herbageis very unstable and decreases rapidly in storage, so that during the late winter months or stall-feeding, the ration may be practically devoid of carotene. Most observations in this connection have been made in countries where the stall-feeding period is shorter than in Canada. Similarstudies have not been made under Quebec conditions. [...]A study has been made of the carotene and Vitamin A content of milk produced by cows, fed under ordinary conditions of stall-reeding. Such a study was necessary in order to arrive at a conclusion regarding the need of a green supplement in the dairy ration.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the factors governing the sex ratio in Chelonus Annulipes Wesm., a braconid parasite of the European corn borer.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the introduction and attempted establishment of imported insect parasites of insect pests, it becomes necessary or desirable, at certain timesand with certain species, to breed numbers of them in the laboratory. In practically all cases where breeding of hymenopterous parasites has beenattempted, 'one of the chief difficulties has been that of securing a ratio of females to males comparable to that occurring in nature, where inthis order the females are usually in excess of the males. Since, in most of the parasitic Hymenoptera so far studied, males will fertilize morethan one female, the success of laboratory breeding operations is in proportion to the number of females which can be reared. The desirability ofinvestigating the factors governing the production of females at once becomes apparent. Any contribution to the knowledge of the operation of suchfactors would be of considerable value to biological control work. [...]The experiments carried out indicate that many of the environmental facto~s which it was felt were important in their relation to sex ratio inChelonus have no significance. It appears also that the reduced number of females secured in the laboratory is the result of lack of fertilization of a sufficientnumber of the eggs laid by mated females and not of any selective eliminationo The practice of rearing the parasitized host larvae at hightemperatures is shown to reduce the number of females in the offspring. In the laboratory many successive generations of this species have beenreared without any new introductions of stock. It is very probable that considerable inbreeding has occurred. This is also shown to affect the sexratio adversely. It is the writer's ,opinion that these two factors have sufficient significance to explain the low number of females obtained inthe laboratory.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chrysene and derivatives.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]In our detailed study of the synthesis, results dis_closed a number of difficulties encountered in the Reformatsky reaction and a seriousirregularity in the last step in the oxidation to the quinone. A compound, also a quinone, always appeared in the oxidation product as acontaminant but no mention of it was made in the original literature. Attempts were made, therefore, to determine the optimum conditions forsecuring the amphi-ohrysenequinone in good yield. In the following section we have presented a description of the work dealing with the Reformatskyreaction, the intermediate steps and the final oxidation. The evidence which ultimately led us to a method of securing the 2,8- oramphi-chrysenequinone in satisfactory yield will be fully described.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The secretory activity of the pancreatic gland in relation to carbohydrate metabolism.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]In the past it has been shown by numerous workers that the secretions of the digestive glands are controlled by nervous and humoral influencesand that by these means their functions are integrated in order to fulfill the alimentary needs of the animal body. It has long been realized bythese and other writers that the processes of secretion, activated by either nervous or humoral stimuli, involve a certain expenditure of energy;and in recent years various writers have concerned themselves with the study of this aspect of secretion. In this connection, they have describedin considerable detail the metabolic changes initiated in the glands by secretory stimulation. From their reported experiments the conclusion maybe drawn that the same principles whioh govern the metabolism of contracting muscle also apply to the activated digestive glands. However, therehas been little attempt on the part of these writers to analyze their findings in terms of the functional regulation of the glands in question. This wouldnecessitate the correlation of the present knowledge of factors which are primarily concerned in the regulation of the glandular cells with theknowledge of the metabolic factors which are concerned in the secretory response of the cells. Such a correlation correlation has been attemptedin the present investigation. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.
Pancreas -- Secretions.
Carbohydrates -- Metabolism.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: I. Aryl iododihalides as halogenating Agents : II. 9-Phenyl decalin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The introduction of fluorine into organic molecules has always been extremely difficult and unsatisfaotory. On acoount of its extreme reaotivity and the difficulty encountered in handling fluorine gas, no satisfactory method for direot fluorination has ever been developed.The usual way of preparir~ organic fluorine compounds has been to avoid direot fluorination and to use as a fluorinating agent some inorganic fluoride having readily replaoeable fluorine or by the diazo reaotion in the oase of aromatio oompounds. If there were any organic oompounds containing loosely bound fluorine it might be possible to use tilem for fluorination. For some time aryl iododichlorides have been known and prepared by a number of investigators. Keppler (1) found that when phenyliododiohloride was exposed to the action of sunlight in a sealed tube for three days there was a slow decomposition and p-ohloroiodobenzene was isolated from the produots. Thus phenyliodod1ohloride has ohlorinated its own benzene nuoleus. Although no instanoe has been reported in the literature it seems likely that it should much more easily give up chlorine to aliphatic unsaturated compounds. In an analogous manner to that of Keppler, Rinkes (2) showed that small amounts of 0- and p-fluoroiodobenzene oould be obtained from phenyliododifluoride by heating it on a waterbath for one-half hour and keeping three months at room temperature; somewhat larger amounts of diphenyl were isolated.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Flouride

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: I. Aryl iododihalides as halogenating Agents : II. 9-Phenyl decalin.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The introduction of fluorine into organic molecules has always been extremely difficult and unsatisfaotory. On acoount of its extreme reaotivity and the difficulty encountered in handling fluorine gas, no satisfactory method for direot fluorination has ever been developed.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The size and composition of the Canadian family : with special reference to sample areas of the metropolitan regions in central Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: From the standpoint of social change the most significant process of the present is the rapid industrialization of new areas like the central areaof Canada. In the development of this new type of economic and social organization, people are being mobilized into vast new aggregates;in thecourse of this they are cut away from their moorings, whether these be thought ot in terms of birthplace, social position or established customsand traditions. Such an upheaval. leaves few areas of human life unchanged. The present study attempts to describe what is happening to the size ofthe family as it adjusts to these new conditions. [...]The forces acting unfavorably on the family tend likewise to reduce its size. Mobility and communication are achieved in a city, in part, bysacrificing space. Children do not harmonize with the crowded living conditions of urban life. While the conditions of urban living are inimicalto traditional family life, the attitude of rational choice allows one to seek alternatives. Emancipation of women has gone on to the place wheremany prefer a work career to married life, and the bachelor apartment allows them to live an individualized life. It is inevitable that a secularattitude in people would result in their experimenting with contraceptive methods. Where children conflict with one Ta attempts to achieve acoveted status, this phase of family life comes into the realm of rational control and technique.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sociology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Development of the confused flour beetle as affected by saturation deficiency and temperature.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Since atmospheric moisture is known to be an important factor of climate influencing the life processes of insects, it seemed worth whileinvestigating further some of the ways in which it affects development. The question as to the best method of representing this factor is still anunsettled one, although from theoretical considerations and. some evidence, it appears that saturation deficit should most nearly satisfy therequirements.The insect studied was the "confused flour beetle, Tribolium confusum Duval, chosen largely because of its suitability for experimental purposes.On account of the magnitude of the experiment, this part of the study deals only with the egg stage. A technique was devised in accordance with the requirements of the experiment. At each of four temperatures, six different saturation deficiencies were maintained. In each of the twentyfourconditions there were placed fifteen lots of ten eggs each, or 3600 egg.s studied in 360 separate lots. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The preparation and properties of pure hydrogen peroxide solutions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis describes research work involving four distinct problem, namely: the purification and concentration of aqueous solutions of hydrogenperoxide, a determination of the freezing point and melting-point curves of the system: water-hydrogen peroxide, a systematic investigation of thevapor-pressures and boiling-points of binary solutions of hydrogen peroxide and water and a comparative study of the rates of decomposition of bothhydrogen and deuterium peroxide by homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts.This work is the continuation of a whole series of investigations carried out in this laboratory,on the properties of pure hydrogen peroxide (...).The method of preparation of the pure peroxide is still essentially the same as that devised by Maass and Hatcher (...). It includes three mainoperations: 1. Purification of the raw commercial product by straight distillation under reduced pressure; 2. Concentration of this pure solutionup to about 95% by two fractional distillations also under low pressure; 3. Separation of the remaining water by fractional crystallization. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Gastric secretion and motility in certain vertebrates.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]I thought it possible that a study of the secretory and motor functions of the stomach of the lower vertebrates might reveal importantinformation about the phylogenetic history of the mammalian stomach. I undertook this investigation of gastric secretion and motility in the lessorganized vertebrates in the belief that it would lead to an approach of a better understanding of the complicated secretory and motor processesof the stomach of the more highly organized mammals.The following vertebrate animals were employed: Elasmobranch fishes (skate), Amphibia (Necturus or mud-puppy, andfrog), and birds (pigeon and chicken). Early in the research many differences in gastric physiology between these lower vertebrates and the mammalswere found. With the view of determining whether the gastric processes of the lower forms were recapitulated in the ontogeny of the mammal, I usedthe stomach of the mammalian foetus and new-born (cat and dog). Finally, since the lower vertebrates (except birds) were cold-blooded animals, Idecided to investigate a mammal that has a low body temperature. For this purpose I chose the groundhog during hibernation.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Gastrointestinal system -- Motility.
Stomach -- Secretions.
Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The kinetics of heterogeneous gas reactions : the decomposition of nitrous oxide on the surface of silver.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The main points of interest obtained from the experimental results are: 1. The reaction is retarded by the oxygen formed in it according to theequation above, due to the preferential adsorption of the oxygen. 2. Oxygen added in large quantities tends to swamp out the effect of oxygenformed in the reaction, so that the reaction becomes virtually first order. This holds unti1 the concentration of added oxygen is equal to or lessthan that of the nitrous oxide. 3. With small amounts of added oxygen the reaction rate :follows the retarded reaction equation except that theslope is different when plotted, varying with the concentration of the added ·oxygen. 4. Added oxygen is no:,t as efficient in retarding the reactionas that formed in the reaction. This is probably due to a slight time lag before desorption.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The development of a method for measuring heat conductivity of colloidal systems under constant humidity conditions. Thermal conductivities of cellulosic materials.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: There is no experimenta1 method adapted tor the investigation of the heat conductivity or co11oidal systems whose structure is dependent onthe amount of adsorbed water. The presence ot the adsorbed water depends on the relative humidity, and therefore a variable temperature gradientwill produce a displacement of water involving the transfer of heat. The main object of this investigation was to develop an experimentaltechnique whereby heat conductivities can be measured in spite of this effect.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Political Fiction of Benjamin Disraeli.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Disraeli's fiction is of interest to few people to-day. He is read only by those ·who wish to study him. as a literary figure, by thosewho wish to study his Tory democracy as propounded in the novel form, and lastly by those few who enjoy the novels for the intrinsic merits theypossess. Despite their brilliance, the novels are essentially political or social, and the average reader of today refuses to accept politicaldissertations and detailed information of the Parliamentary history of the mid-nineteenth century as essential elements of fiction. Disraeli,amid the spectacle of mid nineteenth century naturalism, is an imperfect realist. He is often mystical, end more often idealistic, and thesequalities are not particularly admired in fiction to-day, especially when presented in so elaborate and grandiloquent a style as Disraeli's.However, despite the fact that his works are seldom to be found on the shelves of private libraries to-day, Disraeli's works established acompletely new genre in English fiction, and they hold an unique place in the history of English literature. Disraeli was not the originator ofpolitical fiction, but that he made an important contribution to this new literary genre, and that he established the political novel with apurpose in English literature, there can be no doubt. If he was not an inspired guide to the human race,he was, at least, one of its greatest showmen. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English.
